entry.title: Proverbs - ChapterÂ 11
entry.content:
Context

These are my notes from reading Proverbs, one of the books in the bible. Almost the entire book is a collection of proverbs - short sayings that are generally true. I presume there is some structure and themes in their arrangement, taking notes should help these become clearer and hopefully also help me remember and apply themÂ better.

The book is split up into chapters, which are quite short sections of the book. It would probably take about a minute or two to read each one. The chapters are further split up into verses. In Proverbs each verse seems to be oneÂ sentence.

Numbering the text like this is useful because it lets you refer precisely to a part of the book. Proverbs does have a few headings, but they are too far apart to provide enough structure on their own, IÂ think.

Iâ€™ve read this book a couple of times before, and appreciated it even when I could feel that I was missing most of the wisdom in it. The book is quite easy to read - the sentences are short and the analogies seem simpleÂ enough.

Itâ€™s refreshing to read something that has existed for thousands of year, has withstood criticisms, and feels approachable. Itâ€™s practical, despite being old and written in a completely different cultural context. I find thisÂ comforting.

Text

Each proverb contrasts justice and injustice using a variety of phrases and images. Pride and humility, integrity and crookedness, righteousness andÂ wickedness.

In the context of these qualities, various situations are described: a false balance, disgrace, wisdom,Â riches.

The proverbs are somewhat exaggerated, which seems reasonable given that they are self contained single sentences tasked with defining and then resolving a problem. The imagery is clear, it does not rely onÂ subtlety.

The biggest themes are that honesty, integrity, righteousness are to be valued, and their opposites are to be avoided at all costs. Each of these qualities are in fact actions, not sentiments, and the consequences of these actions are reliable and consistent, and inevitable. The advice to â€œlove your neighbor like yourselfâ€ is a good summary of many of theÂ proverbs.

Its clarity and confidence is encouraging. Do good and good things will happen, do evil and the consequences are inevitably bad forÂ you.

OutstandingÂ proverbs

  • The fruit of the righteous is a tree of life, and whoever captures souls is wise - the first part sounds wonderful. Who wouldnâ€™t want to produce life? The second part is surprising. What is the â€œcapturingÂ soulsâ€?
  • The desire of the righteous ends only in good, the expectation of the wicked in wrath. - this isÂ encouraging
  • One gives freely, yet grows all the richer; another withholds what he should give, and only suffers want. - counter-intuitive
  • Like a gold ring a pigâ€™s snout is a beautiful woman without discretion - this doesnâ€™t seem to fit in with any proverbs around it. Is this the only mention of a woman in this section? Why is it important enough to be included? Does this imply that beauty is discreet? There is surely a big cultural gap between Amsterdam in 2021 and where ever this was firstÂ written.
  • A man who is kind benefits himself, but a cruel man hurts himself. - this is good toÂ know

Conclusion

  • Donâ€™t lie, cheat, steal or plot. Treat people like you yourself would want to beÂ treated.
  • Make an effort to do good and increase justice, and things will go well forÂ you.
  • God delights in blameless people, and he abhors people with crookedÂ hearts.
  • Beauty without discretion is an incongruousÂ waste.

entry.title: My LifeÂ Expectancy
entry.content:
KeyÂ points:

  1. Weight doesnâ€™tÂ matter.
  2. Be in â€œexcellentâ€Â health.
  3. Workout 3 or 4 times aÂ week.
  4. Drink liquor (or red wine) 3 or 4 times a week (after eachÂ workout).
  5. Try to be happy, optimistic and relaxed. What are you working so hard for anyway? You need something to do, someone to love, something to hopeÂ for.

LongevityÂ Calculations

I was playing with the life expectancy calculator at blueprintincome1 and was surprised to find that their regression technique gives me a 50% chance of living to 95! Iâ€™d expected a result closer toÂ 80.

After printing out a 90 year calendar, my next thought was to play with the calculator to find the maximum age I could have a 50% chance ofÂ reaching.

Doing the factors below would apparently giveÂ me:

  • 75% chance of living toÂ 92
  • 50% change of living toÂ 101
  • 25% chance of living toÂ 107

Donâ€™t workout everyÂ day

There is no additional benefit from working out more than 4 times a week. Once youâ€™re fit and working out 4 times a week it doesnâ€™t matter if you do moreÂ exercise.

Being in â€œexcellentâ€ health is better than being in â€œvery goodâ€ health though, so make the workouts count. I guess if it didnâ€™t make a difference then it wouldnâ€™t be excellent in the firstÂ place.

Drink moreÂ alcohol

I was surprised that having 3-4 drinks each week increases your life expectancy. I thought that it was best to not drink any alcohol atÂ all.

I should be drinking red wine or liquor 3 or 4 times each week. Liquor increases longevity in men, but reduces longevity for women. Red wine increases longevity in women, but has no effect in men2. I guess I should drink some rum after eachÂ workout.

Weight doesnâ€™t make aÂ different

According to their regression, my expected longevity is unchanged within a weight range of 78kg - 90kg. I guess itâ€™s much more important that Iâ€™m in â€œexcellentâ€ health, working out 4 times a week and having some wine, rum, or whiskey after eachÂ workout.

But itâ€™s justÂ statistics

The calculator only asks for quantifiable or physical attributes. It doesnâ€™t consider emotional, relational or spiritualÂ factors.

  1. There is also a more detailed calculator at projectbiglife, its calibrated for Canadian citizens. â†©
  2. Alcohol consumption in later life and reaching longevity: the Netherlands Cohort Study â†©

Articles and blog posts I saved to readÂ later:

The Architecture Behind A One-Person TechÂ Startup

An article by Anthony Najjar Simon about how he runs his one-man SaaS usingÂ Django.

  • Low stress, one-person company, run from aÂ flat.
  • Self-funded, taking things slow - he likes taking things slow.
  • Grateful to be standing on the shoulders of the open source giants who went ahead and made the OSS stack we all enjoy and benefitÂ from.
  • Your own context matters when choosing a tech stack. There is no â€œholy grailâ€. I guess this means that you should use what youâ€™re familiar with and what is boring forÂ you.
  • Uses K8s on AWS. He says â€œdont fall into the trap of thinking you need to use it tooâ€ - expertise with these tools was learnt over several years fighting fires on the dayÂ job.
  • Productive because he used the tools he is most familiar with and he can focus onÂ shipping.
  • Django, Celery, PostgreSQL, Python, AWS, Redis. - same as MoneyBar andÂ PipPip.

Boring tech behind a one personÂ SaaS

  • The tech-stack keepsÂ evolving
  • â€œBoringâ€ means â€œwhat Iâ€™m familiar with so that I can focus on theÂ businessâ€
  • Most of his time is spent talking to people and thinking. He spends 15% of his time on engineering. Probably it was more when he was setting stuffÂ up.
  • The methods described in the post are definitely not the best way. Itâ€™s just one way of doing engineering in a very specific type of business. Itâ€™s not the onlyÂ way.
  • Django, Celery, PostgreSQL, Python, AWS, Redis. - same as MoneyBar andÂ PipPip.
  • Uses Ansible for provisioning machines. - YAML files. Should look intoÂ this.
  • â€œGood enough forÂ nowâ€
  • Doesnâ€™t use CI tools, he uses Ansible with a shell script heÂ wrote.
  • Uses Datadog for monitoring and alerting, andÂ PagerDuty.
  • Uses Rollbar, which seems similar toÂ Sentry.
  • Uses Slack, not to talk with humans, but integrations with Rollbar and Datadog, and also slack incoming webhooks to be notified when someone signs up or does something interesting like deletes aÂ thing.
  • Make a â€œdingâ€ sound whenever someone signsÂ up.
  • Heâ€™s always very careful about operational stuff to prevent downtime and outages. Servers are over-provisioned to protect against spikes caused by sudden mediaÂ interest.
  • Avoids working from home or cafe cos its more productive in an office. Productivity is important - make every minute count. He doesnâ€™t often work more than 8Â hours/day.
  • He optimizes for spending less time and making money instead of more time and savingÂ money.
  • Uses Vagrant and virtualbox on an MBP so that dev work is on the same systems as prodÂ infra.
  • Uses 1 monolithic repo. Likes thisÂ approach.
  • He uses contractors!!
  • Usually, the biggest obstacle to building and shipping things is overthinking. What if this, what if that. You are not important at all and no one cares. No one sees. Even if you screw up the initial product launch, no one will care because theyâ€™re not looking. Only when youâ€™ve proved that you deserve their attention will you have any attention andÂ visibility.
  • Think big, start small, act fast.
  • Use boring technology, or whatever tech you want. Just make sure youâ€™re solving an actualÂ problem.
  • Ignore the cargo cult people and ignore the noise. Keep calm and carryÂ on.

Djangos place in a web developmentÂ world

  • Not everything needs to be an SPA
  • Django is a back-end framework, itâ€™ll work with an front-end framework, because separation ofÂ concerns.
  • To use django with an SPA, you could use DRF, or just normal views that return JSON.
  • Reading this makes me want to check out React to see what all the fuss isÂ about.

Cache invalidation

VimÂ abbreviations

  • Cool and all, but not as powerful as snippets IÂ think.
  • Auto correcting typos: teh ->Â the
  • Expanding phrases: kr -> kindÂ regards
  • Multi-line textÂ expansion.
  • It really seems similar to what Iâ€™m using UltiSnipsÂ for.
  • I found this question on SO comparing abbreviations and snippets. TLDR: Itâ€™s easier to add and maintain snippets than abbreviations, and you have less boilerplate with snippets than abbreviations, especially in complexÂ cases.

To fix the social sciences, look to the â€œdark agesâ€ of medicine

Emotional resilience in leadershipÂ report

3 virtues of aÂ programmer

  • Laziness - The quality that makes you go to great effort to reduce overall energy expenditure. It makes you write labor-saving programs that other people will find useful and document what you wrote so you donâ€™t have to answer so many questions aboutÂ it.
  • Impatience - The anger you feel when the computer is being lazy. This makes you write programs that donâ€™t just react to your needs, but actually anticipate them. Or at least pretendÂ to.
  • Hubris - The quality that makes you write (and maintain) programs that other people wonâ€™t want to say bad thingsÂ about.
  • Also, I read a quote somewhere saying the mark of a great program is having people use it in ways you didnâ€™t expect, or something likeÂ that.

Is WebAssembly magic performance pixieÂ dust?

entry.title: Over-Engineering thisÂ blog
entry.content:
Over the last few weeks Iâ€™ve spent an unreasonable amount of time and energy making unnecessary improvements to thisÂ blog.

Some of these improvementsÂ are:

  1. Adding keyboard shortcuts (type ? to find outÂ which).
  2. Implementing, then reimplementing, and then optimizing client side fuzzyÂ search.
  3. Using src-set to serve responsive images (Image-Process).
  4. Lazy loading images to make this site loadÂ faster.
  5. Compressing page files using brotli and also gzip (Precompress).
  6. Trying (and ultimately failing) to avoid a â€œwhite flashâ€ when dark mode is chosen and a new page loads (Github discussion).

Iâ€™m not really sure why I did it. It makes almost no difference to anyone but me. It felt a bitÂ compulsive.

I like tinkering, and itâ€™s nice to build something that will continue to work with no maintenance. I tell myself that over the next few years I will gain the benefits of these features even when Iâ€™ve forgotten I implementedÂ them.

Itâ€™s taught me a lot of JavaScript, which is a great language to be familiar with - itâ€™s everywhere. I would warmly encourage someone younger than myself to pursue interests for the sake of curiosity and fun. And there is a very high chance that even if no-one uses the shortcuts except me, my new javascript skills will come in useful somewhereÂ else.

But even if they do Iâ€™m not sure its a good enough reason - things should be built when they solve a present problem, not over-engineered for what-ifs and maybes. YAGNI. I wouldnâ€™t let myself do this in a professional capacity. There is a tension between being curious and beingÂ focussed.

Iâ€™m not really sure that I need to justify myself. Its a hobby, I wanted to do it, I enjoy tinkering with web technologies and learning newÂ things.

But also, I lost sleep over this - I stayed up too late, and let it put pressure on otherÂ things.

I know that being curious, and making room to play with interesting things, has been one of the most useful approaches to personal development and up-skilling myself. But there must be aÂ limit..

There is a tension between wasting my time and taking a risk, and it will take a few years before I know for sure if these efforts were worthwhile, orÂ not.

If itâ€™s not fun, donâ€™t doÂ it.

Successful business owners seem to be very good at leaving things alone once theyâ€™re â€œgood enoughâ€, and not being perfectionists. In fact, I think that being a perfectionist is antithetical to being an entrepreneur. I am not a perfectionist, Iâ€™m just really curious and have a big appetite forÂ learning.

But this â€œappetite for learningâ€ stops me from focussing. I let myself become distracted by adding new features to this blog, when instead I should zoom out a bit and think about working towards a more substantial and meaningful goal, to the exclusion of more minorÂ goals.

I think that good entrepreneurs are very focussed, to a fault. I am not that focussed. I am too distracted byÂ life.

Itâ€™s a balancing act, there is a tension between being emotionally and physically present with my family and friends, and ignoring as many things as possible so that I can focus on doing something meaningful that is necessarilyÂ hard.

entry.title: CorporateÂ London
entry.summary: Reflections on 3 years living and working in London
entry.content:
2014 -Â 2017

Having made arrangements to leave London, it seems like a reasonable time to reflect on my timeÂ here.

London is a tough city to live in â€” itâ€™s big enough that a sub 1-hour commute is considered good, and itâ€™s super expensive. My stay in London has been defined by my quest to complete my graduate scheme and qualify as anÂ accountant.

When I first arrived I had no idea what London or working in a corporate would be like. I was coming from academia, and my motivation for moving to finance could be summed up in twoÂ points:

  1. Understand more about the 2008 financialÂ crisis
  2. Get paid more for using mostly the same skills (math) as inÂ engineering

I donâ€™t think thereâ€™s anything wrong with these motivations, but I should have been making a long term career planÂ instead.

When I started my job I was surprised at the 6 weeks of induction and hot-desking. Life as an auditor felt nomadic, as everyone would spend large amounts of time at clientâ€™s offices, and no-one has their own desk in our office. The only thing you really own is your knowledge and your network ofÂ relationships.

In 2014, I arrived with a high opinion of my employer and the view that I would be staying for several years. Having escaped the financial insecurity of short-term research grants, Iâ€™d moved back to my home country to contribute to the system that educated me. I was happy to have a regular job with a decent, predictableÂ salary.

A phrase that kept coming to mind back then was â€œaccountant factoryâ€. Our training materials were scripted and everything was a standardised process. We were being processed. Graduates in, corporate accountantsÂ out.

The company is huge and so are the efficiencies and barriers to competition that come with this. When I arrived I was impressed there were free biscuits, and it felt presumptuous to put a meeting in someones diary. Now I ignore any communications addressed to a mailingÂ list.

Accountant

The toughest experiences were related to the accountancy qualification. NaÃ¯vely I had believed that the qualification wouldnâ€™t be a big deal and I didnâ€™t give any thought to it when I applied â€” I just wanted to find out how banks worked. If there were some exams to be done then it would be fine, Iâ€™d already achieved a PhD and I would handleÂ it.

That turned out to be a mistake. A huge mistake. The alarm bells should have rung louder when I realised most of my graduate colleagues had only applied so that they could get the qualification (and were already intending to leave asap afterwards). Doing the pre-course work before college wasnâ€™t trivial. College - I was being sent to a classroom again. We were being taken out of the office, away from clients, and put in a classroom to prepare for theseÂ examsâ€¦

Starting a job that required becoming a chartered accountant, without considering the effort and time involved to qualify was dumb. Itâ€™s an oversight I find hard toÂ believe.

The disappointment and sadness at having to study again was profound. The teaching and assessment style was several steps behind what Iâ€™d become used to. Compared to the depth, autonomy and research-focus of a doctorate, writing cookie-cutter essays in time-pressured exams felt stupid. The exams were hard and I failed several of them, probably because of my low morale whilst revising. Retaking them required more weekends and annual leave being spent away from my family, camped-out in libraries andÂ offices.

This required much patience and generosity from Ritsya, who having not seen me for long periods during my doctorate expected us to have a more normal lifestyle when we came to London. I found it miserable to pause my social life and other interests whilst studying, and then I would try to rush back to them when I had the time, knowing that soon Iâ€™d have to pause themÂ again.

If I hadnâ€™t already studied in Vienna, this process of working and studying in London would have been exciting and felt valuable or special. Iâ€™d passed enough exams though to know that theyâ€™re never as important as theyâ€™re made out to be, and whatever it was that was missing from my life wasnâ€™t going to be found in anotherÂ qualification.

On the upside though, the ACA is the most practical qualification Iâ€™ve gained and has taught me many useful aspects of business and finance. Iâ€™m glad to finally see business not as some mysterious system but something attainable andÂ understandable.

Neighbourhood

Living in London has also required a lot of time on trains â€” my door to desk commute is about an hour each way, and Iâ€™ve never lived somewhere in London that hasnâ€™t felt transient. Weâ€™ve needed to live near a station and didnâ€™t want to commute more than an hour and thatâ€™s put us in neighbourhoods with other young professionals who also donâ€™t have long term plans (or financial ability) to stay in the city. Weâ€™re all looking to move on and move up as fast as possible. I want to leave London partly because there are so many people with the same attitudes and priorities as myÂ ownâ€¦

CorporateÂ Culture

Back in the office I spent the first few months figuring out how people were organised, how teams operated and how decisions were made. I think it took me about a year to feel like I understood how things really worked, and 1.5 years to feel like I could do all aspects of my job with certainty. There is a difference between how things are spoken about, and how things actuallyÂ happen.

My experience has been that performance is all that matters and behaviour is defined by self-interest. I donâ€™t think this is different from previous environments Iâ€™ve worked in â€” academia isnâ€™t any different1 and the construction industry certainly isnâ€™t. I wonder if the only way people can endure it is if theyâ€™ve not experienced anything else, or think it normal, or necessary. I find myself wishing we could be kinder to each other, and that we could create structures that incentivise mutualÂ support.

Corporate finance usually appears clean and well presented. Its people appear dependable and capable. The culture is sanitised and thereâ€™s a lot of pressure to conform - you can see it in the clothes and accessories we wear and the jokes we tell each other in theÂ canteen.

I came to see my office as a glass and steel cathedral. I read about the Middle East, and migrants arriving in Europe, and tower blocks burning, and felt reallyÂ disconnected.

Despite the high regard with which we hold ourselves, we donâ€™t ask each other how we can help. Maybe we are too busy, or feel powerless to help. Apparently we do not know how to help, despite our wealth, talents, education andÂ connections.

I remember watching a man leave the office one day and thought that if he gave his whole career and left his firm after decades of service, there would be nothing left to identify him after a few weeks. The work will always get done. Market forces will dictate how the business adapts and grows. The City rollsÂ on.

  1. Publications trump almost all other metrics, and the incentives to publish quantity over quality are such that risky or slow research is inexcusable. The metrics used to standardise success and allocate resources can be subverted just as well in academia as in any other industry. What management measures, the team prioritises.Â â†©

entry.title: Move
entry.content:
Ambition

Since I was 15, one of my ambitions has been to be an entrepreneur. I used to joke with my dad about buying him a nice boat oneÂ day.

Life so far has been predominantly about education, and that stage is over now. Iâ€™m walking away from what Iâ€™ve come to see as a lifestyle and career that has too many contradictions, it doesnâ€™t make sense to live like this. Ultimately I want to develop multiple sources of passive income. I want toÂ create.

SummerÂ 2017

The last few months have been intense, with some weeks leaving me feeling ambitious and energetic, and others feeling anxious and overwhelmed. I need to get better at defining a goal, taking the quickest path there, and ignoring interestingÂ distractions.

Ritsya is brave enough and imaginative enough to force me to think big and consider how to live a better life. My biggest fear is that I screw it up, shooting myself in the foot and Ritsya and my daughter also. We were headed safely to an unremarkable existence and it would be terrible to swap that for something worse. That wonâ€™tÂ happen.

I know that I make better decisions and produce my best work under pressure, I thrive when Iâ€™m perceived as an underdog. I need to accept this without using it as a reason to be foolish. Whilst I donâ€™t have a clear plan, or direction, or goal, (I have many of them) Iâ€™ve got skills and I want to see what I can make. I think those risks are overpriced, and most people are more capable than they realise. Sometimes you have to walk into a situation to find out how to make the most of it. And sometimes you have to leave a place in order to gainÂ perspective.

AutumnÂ 2016

Last year my boss gave me some advice that was supposed to be encouraging. Iâ€™d requested to reduce my involvement with some stuff that was unrelated to my job so that I could contribute more to my team and still maintain some semblance of a work/lifeÂ balance.

entry.title: London Rent vs. LondonÂ Salaries
entry.summary: Living in London is only financially possible if you are either single or household income is more than Â£60k/year.
entry.content:
Living in London is expensive, everyone in the UK knows this. Everyone knows that this is mostly due to the price of property, which we all enjoy talkingÂ about.

Iâ€™ve lived here for 3 years now, and when my wife and I were both working we lived comfortably. Two incomes under one roof is just fine. Not as fine as in many other cities, but reasonable. Just over a year ago my first child was born, and now that my wifeâ€™s maternity pay has ended we are a single income household. This is notÂ fine.

Even though I earn almost Â£50k/year, and any salary increase will be taxed at 40%, I cannot cover essential day-to-day costs. Iâ€™m in the 40% tax bracket, and my basic monthly outgoings exceed my monthly take home pay by Â£400. If my employer wanted to pay me enough to cover essential costs, it would cost them approximately double the shortfall due to tax. None of this makesÂ sense.

Salaries and living expenses have become reallyÂ disconnected.

For most people the most obvious way to increase wealth is to buy property. Mortgage repayments are cheaper than rent, and the value of the property increases over time. Double win. But there is a big hurdle to overcome before this is possible - saving money for a deposit on a house is often impossible without external help (i.e. the â€œBank of Mum and Dadâ€), because so much of the money earnt must be spent on rentÂ first.

Itâ€™s a trap. Repayments on a mortgage are cheaper than paying rent, but you cannot save enough for a depositÂ because;

  1. so much of your salary goes to paying rent1,Â and
  2. the average cost of a flat in London is 500k2, which means a 5% deposit is Â£25k â€” which is a higher deposit than you would need anywhere else in the UK, despite being the place you are least able to accumulateÂ it.

What if my partner went back to work and we put our baby in childcare? Childcare is not cheap, and working would need to bring in more than the cost of childcare. This requires a higher than average salary from a graduate job, (which is the life stage when people might reasonably start having children), so unless both parents are unusually high earners that option isnt viableÂ either.

Living in London is only financially possible if you are either single or household income is more thanÂ Â£60k/year.
